author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> I think we have decided that state expiry can at the very least postponed by several years if we implement verkle, if it is required at all. So we intentionally now restructured most of the work to not be based on state expiry anymore and make verkle viable even if state expiry is never implemented

author: draganrakita
content: How is it being postponed by verkle? There are other good reasons to, but just wondering what is this connection

author: yperbasis
content: A bigger state is a constant toll you pay on each state access operation. Fundamentally, it's some kind of trees all the way down (either in memory or on disk), so roughly speaking the cost of each access operation is `O(log n)`, where `n` is the size of the state. Even if `n` is not big enough to present a problem for the sync time or the disk space, a bigger `n` is always a drag on the performance.

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> Verkle massively reduces the number of nodes that need to keep the state locally, in particular, you will not need the state (and keep updating it) if what you need to know is just which block is the current head
